Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of new auto plants under construction by stating that "many, many plants are now under construction" when in reality there are only two new assembly plants under construction or newly announced.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence provided to back up the statement that "many, many plants are now under construction." The expert's verdict only mentions two new assembly plants.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the auto industry hasn't built a new plant "in decades," which is not true as there have been several new assembly plants announced since 2009.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there have been new auto plants built in recent years, including Volvo's plant in South Carolina and Mercedes-Benz's plant in South Carolina.
Understate: The claim understates the number of new plants by stating that they "hadn't built one in decades" when there have been multiple new plants announced since 2009.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not provide an alternative explanation for the construction of new auto plants, such as changes in industry trends or economic factors.
